author: New Age Leader

text:
This song plays like climbing a mountain:
0:00 Begin first portion of climb
0:27 Think you've reached the peak but you see more ahead after, climb down from small peak
0:32 Keep climbing to the lower cloud levels
0:49 Reach a high cloudy plateau that is foggy
1:04 Clouds clear and MASSIVE mountain reveals itself
1:32 Keep climbing
1:57 Air gets really thin and cold... Keep climbing
2:30 Lose service, and gets lost, but keep climbing uphill
2:38 Summit becomes visible! Final stretch!
3:20 You did it!! Summit reached!!
3:38 Oxygen critically low, go down...
3:48 Way back down
author: Jacob Lepley

text: Great comment! But I think 3:20 sounds more like you see that there's an even higher peak, so the journey continues with newly found ambition.

author: BlackestManInTheVillage

text: This is still undeniably one of the hardest platformers I have ever played, but the soundtrack keeps me coming back to it, not to mention the outright difficult bosses and level design. It's ironic that my mother only bought me two games for the system after my parents divorced, both picked from the discount bin at the video store, both games composed by Tim and Geoff Follin, and both considered relative failures on the system, yet both games share an amazing soundtrack. Although Plok is leaps and bounds a better game than Spiderman and X-Men in Arcade's Revenge
author: Justin Beck

author: James Peterson

text:
This sounds more like Gentle Giant than Genesis. Maybe portions of Selling England-era Genesis (like on "Cinema Show" and "Firth of Fifth"), but this sounds much more like the Power and the Glory, In a Glass House and Free Hand had a baby and it was being played on a SNES.

Portions also sound like Mental Notes-era Split Enz (specifically the longer songs, i.e. "Stranger Than Fiction," "Under the Wheel"), H to He-era VdGG, and Camel during the Mirage days. I keep hearing some Cardiacs influence, but I don't know what specifically. Maybe their slower and less erratic works?
author: Hal Emmerich

text: Tim's early Jethro Tull influences can be heard in this track too, I think of "Living In The Past" (the bass line e.g..) though that was in 5/4
author: Dennis Lindroos

text:
Hal that may be but the climaxes of the song are 100% Tony Banks sounding. 0:55 - 1:24 and 3:18 - 3:36 as a couple examples are more late 70s Tony writing than.... most anything I've ever heard. Like Wind and Wuthering... (which I already mentioned... I hope you've heard that record) and A Curious Feeling in particular. Parts of And Then There Were Three as well. Also his piece "Submarine" from the 80s. But yeah honestly actually I see how you could feel Gentle Giant for everything besides those bits. 
And Dennis hell yeah I feel that!
author: James Peterson

author: MRCHOCOTACO

text: I remember playing this as a kid and recalling how great the soundtrack was, it was definitely ahead of its time in terms of progressive music on a video game console, I don't think too many people got to appreciate it since either they were too busy playing the game or never played it at all. This was during a time when VGM just wasn't appreciated like it is now, with the internet being able to reach out and show more people.
author: neoasura

text: What a nice track! Hypnotizing and quite psychedelic. It's effectively progressive rock, yet "videogamish" enough to appeal even to little kids. And those who like prog rock, folk rock and trance can all find a reason to enjoy it. I can hear some Jean Michel Jarre, and the sound at 2:29 slightly reminds me of one of the songs from Terminator 2: Judgment Day for the NES (music by Geoff Follin, pretty damn awesome soundtrack if you ask me). The Follin brothers are epic!

author: MelmanOfDaSouthh

text:
Not really. Tim liked them, but said he wanted a stable income, so he left the VGM business forever - which is a huge shame, as he is one of the best composers to ever walk the Earth.
Geoff loved games, and good music - he was Tim's main influence on both fronts. I can't recall why he quit, but I do know none of them hated videogames.
Hell, if you hated the girl next door, would you learn to and then make a three story chocolate cake to give it to her? I think not. Same applies here.

text: 0:55 to 1:32 is just incredible. You'd seriously think this was from the early N64 era by the quality of this music. Thanks to Creepy Crag making the list, borrowed my friend's game and spent a solid day beating it. Incredible gem, I am amazed I didn't hear of it until now. Great list SupraDarky, always reminded that subscribing was one of the better choices I've made in life :)

text: This soundtrack was composed by Tim Follin, a famous composer. His two most celebrated console soundtracks are Equinox (SNES) and Ecco the Dolphin (Dreamcast & PS2).
